values.alignmentText: No private tech sector; programming jobs are state-assigned, leaving no path for .NET careers.
Coal heating and outdated industry leave urban air dusty, a concern for our kids.
State atheism removes religious pressure but reflects oppressive control rather than pluralism.
Totalitarian rule eliminates civil liberties and risks our family values.
Sanctions and state banks make cards useless; cash rationing dominates daily life.
Coastline exists but public beach access and amenities are nearly nonexistent.
Hobby markets are banned and gatherings monitored, stifling board-game communities.
State-run nurseries exist but resources and autonomy are limited.
Urban infrastructure is crumbling and surveillance heavy, making cities unfriendly for kids.
Work units may provide childcare but quality is poor and indoctrination heavy.
Foreign families rarely reside here and receive no childcare support.
Few leisure activities are permitted, leaving little overlap with our interests.
Social life is dictated by the state; trust outside assigned groups is risky.
Minor infractions can lead to severe punishment under pervasive surveillance.
Prices can be low but goods are scarce and often require bribes.
Dual citizenship is not recognized by the regime.
Sanctions and central planning keep the economy stagnant with little opportunity.
A strict command economy leaves no room for market entrepreneurship.
Schools focus on ideology with limited resources and poor global outcomes.
Foreign employment is nearly impossible; there is no sponsorship channel.
Deforestation and pollution outweigh limited scenic areas.
Income for foreigners is uncommon and tax rules are opaque and arbitrary.
Autumn runs about 5–20°C (41–68°F), crisp but data is limited.
State dictates family roles and discourages alternative relationship structures.
Bringing dependents is discouraged; foreign families are rare.
Pro-natalist benefits exist but depend on political loyalty.
Policies support only state-approved nuclear families.
Foreign families receive no meaningful support or recognition.
Conservative, state-approved dress leaves little room for expression.
Uniform styles are expected, curbing personal style.
Traditional roles are enforced, limiting gender expression.
There is no commercial game industry or indie scene.
Gender nonconformity is repressed by law and custom.
Women have nominal equality but face strict expectations and limited rights.
Rigid patriarchal roles dominate daily life.
Foreigners face constant monitoring and severe movement restrictions.
Floods and droughts may intensify, and infrastructure is ill-prepared.
Universal in name but medicine and equipment shortages are common.
Foreigners rely on limited clinics with minimal capabilities.
University access hinges on political loyalty rather than merit.
Foreign students are rarely admitted outside propaganda programs.
Housing is allocated by work units, often cramped and poorly maintained.
Personal taxes are opaque; the state extracts resources through work units.
State schools exist nationwide but are heavily indoctrinating.
No international schools for outsiders; enrollment is exceptional.
Homosexuality is unacknowledged and severely repressed.
English is rarely spoken; Korean is mandatory everywhere.
Juche draws from Marxism-Leninism but is enforced dogma rather than open discourse.
Militaristic culture prizes traditional masculinity and conformity.
Unauthorized gatherings are prohibited, hindering any community events.
State wages are symbolic and inadequate for family needs.
Infrastructure is antiquated with frequent power and service outages.
Mountain landscapes and rivers are scenic yet largely inaccessible.
Typhoons and floods regularly cause damage due to poor mitigation.
Travel restrictions make it hard to reach natural areas.
Entertainment is state-run and lacks diversity or spontaneity.
Curfews and surveillance prevent normal nightlife.
No known game development communities operate openly.
Only small propaganda studios exist; none suit indie goals.
Private startups are forbidden under the command economy.
Rationing slows daily life but surveillance keeps stress high.
Parents are expected to raise loyal citizens under heavy state oversight.
Naturalization is virtually impossible for foreigners.
Bribery is commonplace despite official denials.
A hereditary one-party state offers no democratic participation.
Non-monogamous relationships are illegal and harshly punished.
State nurseries provide care but are underfunded and ideological.
Private schools are banned outright.
The regime promotes ultraconservative nationalism, not progressive values.
The state saturates all media with propaganda, giving rich material to study.
Propaganda is ubiquitous in schools, workplaces, and public spaces.
Pyongyang has a metro but travel elsewhere is tightly restricted.
Religion is absent but replaced with ideological cults, not secular pluralism.
Open internet and remote work are forbidden.
Only short, highly controlled visas are available.
State pensions exist but are small and unreliable.
No pathways exist for foreign retirees.
No market for Ruby developers or modern software roles.
Street crime is low, but political risk and arbitrary detention are high.
Only state-run schools with propaganda are available.
Coastal waters are cool much of the year and facilities are minimal.
Hot humid summers and freezing winters clash with our mild-climate preference.
Sex outside marriage is taboo and heavily censored.
Policies prioritize regime control over personal freedoms.
5–17°C (41–63°F) with frequent dust storms from China.
The regime is rigid but economic shocks and isolation create uncertainty.
Juche ideology demands absolute loyalty, conflicting with our values.
Markets operate only informally; capitalism is effectively banned.
23–30°C (73–86°F) with heavy monsoon humidity.
Visa processes are opaque, expensive, and slow with few approvals.
Public trust is coerced; dissent is dangerous.
Petty bribery and elite graft are common just to access basics.
Salaries are symbolic and insufficient for supporting a family.
Weekends include mandatory community labor and propaganda events.
Long workdays plus political meetings leave little family time.
Official leave is minimal and at the discretion of the work unit.
Even when granted, travel options are heavily restricted.
State media portrays neighbors as hostile enemies.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Neighboring states view the regime with suspicion and concern.
Propaganda promotes self-reliance and superiority, discouraging openness.
Only short tourist visas exist; no immigration pathways.
Americans are rarely admitted and tightly controlled.
The closed system offers unique study in propaganda but little else appealing for family life.
-13–3°C (8–37°F) with biting winds beyond our comfort.
Workers face long hours plus ideological sessions.
State demands override personal and family time.
No independent unions; forced labor and punishments are common.
